recommendations.description: both are about mafia but bungo stray dogs has superpowers while 91 days is a revenge story wiyh realistic fights and physics without any gimmicks

liked.title: Eoneu Nal Jameseo Kkaeeoboni Bagelyeoga Doeeo Isseotda

recommendations.description:
The main characters of these series are extremely similar because they are both a shut-in and happened to become a girl overnight, so both of them has to deal with these changes in their life and there is a character that helps them. 
Both are comedic and has a lot of fanservice.
Both of these series are sports anime that also try to touch on the interpersonal drama of the characters, their families, and their futures.

Friendship is a beautiful concept, but it’s like a white shirt, a speck of dust rids it of the value which had taken both parties so much time to amass. True friendship is a more realistic take, Because true friends stand up for you. If others try to hurt you, they do everything they can to make sure you stay safe. They don't care who is trying to harm you; they will defend you anytime, anywhere. If they can help you, they'll do it without reservation or without expectation of reward. But it’s exactly because of this that conflicts arise - you have to understand these can be resolved.

Before Sohrab, you’ve never really made a true friend. Especially with everything that’s happening around you - you feel so lonely, and it hurts me to see that. I’ve been the same before, too. There was a period of time in my life where I’ve never felt so alone, I wanted nothing more than a friend to laugh with, to play with, even just to argue with. It was exactly them that lifted me into his arms and saved me, pulled me away from the endlessly dark pit I’ve been residing in for all too long, just like it was Sohrab who lifted you into his arms amidst your times of solitude.

- Both are romances set in a historical fantasy world. 
- Both are bittersweet romances between an human and a sassy creature of magic who travel together by wagon.  
- Both humans have a craft they're an expert in, and both series explore it. Medieval economics for Lawrence, Sugar sculpting for Ann.

recommendations.description:

The characters from this series and xxxHolic are recycled into Tsubasa Chronicles, and some lore from CCS comes into play in Tsubasa.

If you love Sugar Apple Fairy Tale you'll also love Snow White with the Red Hair. 

Both are romances in a fairy tale setting. They have a sweet Disney-like feel. Both shows have high-quality, beautiful animation with a bright color palette. 

Both shows have ambitious, driven and strong-willed female leads that are working to master a craft. Medicinal herbalism for Shirayuki, being a sugar sculptor for Anne. Both feature a warrior male lead.

recommendation.title: Inu ni Nattara Suki na Hito ni Hirowareta.

recommendations.description: Both are R+ grade ecchi comedies through the eyes of pet animals who want to get physical with their mistresses. In Inuhiro it's a dog while in Juliet a Scottish Fold cat. Both emphasize low camera angles and no-pan backside fetish in their ecchi part - I guess that's in line with the overall bestiality theme.

recommendation.title: Inu ni Nattara Suki na Hito ni Hirowareta.

recommendations.description: Both are R+ grade ecchi about a dog lusting for his mistress, from the animal's perspective. Both feature low angle POV camera shots, off commentary by the dog, and nopan shots. I guess that's in line with the overall bestiality theme.

Both are Epilogues of their respective series that dive deep into the character's psychology and tie in the loose ends of everything that happened so far. Both series are told  achronologically and the final installments really shines in the psychology of the characters mind. Both involve interesting and deeply philosophical dialogue with unique visuals.
They both feature a main character with a hero complex, which is considered dangerous by everyone else in the cast, and lead them to multiple self-destructive situations.

To Love-Ru was strongly inspired by the original Urusei Yatsura, as they both feature an unlucky human boy who gets accidentally engaged in marriage with an alien girl who has demonic features, so if you liked To Love-Ru, this remake of Urusei Yatsura is for you.
They feature a waifu war where the main character has a past relationship to one of the girls, but can't remember which one, and the one who's chosen by him will become his bride.

Darling in the FranXX is basically an Evangelion rip-off that, unlike most others, doesn't just superficially copy EVA, instead giving its own take on the same themes as it. So both series feature a post-apocalyptic setting, ancient monsters attacking a human city in search of something hidden inside it, teenagers with psychological conflicts being forced to pilot mecha to fight back, sinister head figures with a relationship to aliens, and a strong focus on the mentality of and the relationships between the pilots.
Both shows are comedies that feature an assassin, a spy, and a mind reader (albeit the way these tropes are carried out varies heavily).

recommendation.title: Otonari no Tenshi-sama ni Itsunomanika Dame Ningen ni Sareteita Ken

recommendations.description: In both series, there is a MC that seems incapable of doing anything without the main girl, where she sometimes acts more like a mother figure to him than a romantic interest

If you enjoied "Ansatsu Kyoushitsu" you could start watching "Spy Kyoushitsu"

Here are some similarity of the anime I like:
1. Both have an overpowered teacher you have to beat
2. Both have  some sort of classroom 
3. Both contain students who are washouts and the "losers". 

Since only the first episode is out, I can't tell much about it. But I have the feeling you might enjoy it, if you like any of these aspects. In my case, it really worked out. I like these concepts.
Recommendation goes in both ways, basically.

recommendation.title: Otome Game Sekai wa Mob ni Kibishii Sekai desu

recommendations.description:
- Both anime are isekai (although on Otome he may only be an isekai in appearance, there are several odd clues)
- Both protagonists start from the bottom and are treated as nobodies, only to later have those tasty scenes of social revenge when they become strong 
- Both protagonists get hate at some point 
- Both protagonists do what they want without caring too much and show off their strength in front of everyone constantly
- Both protagonists are betrayed by their friends at some point, although in Otome this event has much less importance to the plot
- Both protagonists find relics that make them stronger
- Both protagonists get to build their own harem, although smaller in Otome (for now?) but on the other hand on the level of how relationships are handled it is more plausible in my opinion
...and more.
Gang war activities in Tokyo. If you're looking for more Durara action then this might be for you. Ikebukuro West Gate Park is more on the realistic side though, so no supernatural activities.

Both stories are incredibly compelling at making you feel. If you're looking for a good tearjerker then this is for you. The story builds up with the few episodes it has, but it really makes you fall in love with the characters, and creates an impact full end to the story. If you like these types of stories i would recommend watching more works from Key

recommendations.description: Both are isekais with OP MCs and they're surrounded by girls of different races and breeds.

This 3-minute special for promoting the NES port/version of Valis: The Fantasm Soldier was directed by 2 famous directors, Katsuhiko Nishijima (yes, the same person who directed Project A-Ko).  The other director is Hideaki Anno (the same Anno who would later create Neon Genesis Evangelion).  If you looked at Yuko's design in the animation promo, she look just like Eiko "A-ko" Magami with blue hair.  Now because Nishijima directed this short alongside Anno, now we know why Yuko in the promo short looks too much like A-Ko in term of character design.

If you want to see A-Ko's look alike, look no further then this anime promo.

This 3-minute special for promoting the NES port/version of Valis: The Fantasm Soldier was directed by 2 famous directors, Hideaki Anno (yes, that same Anno) who would later founded Gainax and created the beloved groundbreaking anime, Neon Genesis Evangelion.  The other director is Katsuhiko Nishijima (director behind Project A-Ko, Agent Aika).

So how is this 3-minute anime promo connected to Kill la Kill?

If you watched the promo carefully near the end, you'll see where Kill la Kill got it's influence from.  Given that this was directed by Hideaki Anno, I suspected Studio Trigger (studio that was formed by former Gainax animators) may have used this 3-minute promo as some sort of inspiration for Kill la Kill.  Yuko Asou fighting another opponent in the promo is very much like Ryuko Matoi's in Kill la Kill.

So this 3-minute promo for a video game was Kill la Kill before Kill la Kill was even created.

Gate Keepers really feels like a spiritual successor to Mob Psycho.

Premise - ESP wielding Japanese teens balance their struggle against the supernatural and maturing alongside their peers. Ensemble cast of quirky, distinctive kids with a variety of powers centered around the Protagonist.

Protagonist - Shigeo is different from Shun certainly. Shigeo's OP, Shun isn't really. But this ties in nicely in my head-canon, because Shun from Gatekeepers is voiced by Sakurai Takahiro, who also voices Reigen on Mob. Shun is always overly cocky and extroverted, so in my mind its kind of like a Reigen-centric coming of age prequel xD 
(What if Reigen had powers as a kid and lost them, and then lies so much to compensate for this loss later in life? :OO)

Bonus connection - The design of one of the characters on GK, Kageyama Reiji, reminds me strongly of when we first meet Hanazawa Teru in Mob. (Blond, aloof, uses powers to gain popularity and influence within the school, etc)

Both female protagonists have voluptuous bodies.

The MC is their "master" while the female is their slave/servant.

They help each other reach their goals while being with each other.

Both female protagonist can be a yandere at times.

Bocchi the Rock! and Kimi ni Todoke are centered on two protagonists that have a complete lack of social skills, which causes them endless difficulties. Sawako (Kimi ni Todoke) is a pure-hearted, and compassionate girl who desperately wants friends, but is constantly bullied for her being scary-looking. Her self-deprecation and naivety creates misunderstandings that she is unable to resolve easily since she has no social skills. Bocchi (Bocchi the Rock!) is a nervous trainwreck in a perpetual state of despair who desperately wants to change and have friends, but is incapable of approaching someone. Her self-deprecation and anxiety makes her lie to escape any situation and to appear normal. Anyone who related to these characters should consider this recommendation.

liked.title: Dungeon ni Deai wo Motomeru no wa Machigatteiru Darou ka

recommendations.description:
If you liked "Dungeon ni Deai wo Motomeru no wa Machigatteiru Darou ka" you also might enjoy "Arifureta Shokugyou de Sekai Saikyou".

Here are some similarity of the anime I like:
1. Both main character have white hair and red eyes
2. Both main character started weak and got abnormally powerful
3. Both have these funny harem elements
4. Both have an adventuring touch
and there is even more.

Although I don't like the harem aspect too much, I love the fact of an insanely powerful main cast. All the similarity make it feel familiar even tough they have different concepts. All in all, I just love this kind of plot line.
Based on this, I recommend this. Recommendation goes in both ways, naturally speaking.
Both stories talk about a teenagers discovering some sort of mystery in a more tropical side of Japan.

If you watched both Bleach & Shakugan no Shana, you'll see a lot of similarities.

-Both involved supernatural after-life life forms that harm humans (Hollows in Bleach, Crimson Denizen/Tomogara in Shakugan no Shana).
-both involved spiritual protectors/enforcers that are human/pseudo-humans (shnigami/soul reapers in Bleach, flame haze in Shakugan No Shana).
-main male character (Yuji Sakai in Shakugan No Shana, Ichigo Kurosaki in Bleach) meet a mysterious female main character (Shana in Shakugan no Shana, Rukia Kuchiki in Bleach).  Although both Yuji and Ichigo can see spirit, they differ a lot by personality, & other things.

So if you are a fan of Bleach, chances are you might find Shakugan No Shana to fit your taste given that the premise of both titles are very similar.

Both Fire Tripper & Inuyasha were created by Rumiko Takahashi.  If you watched both of them, you'll see a lot of similarities.

Suzuko (Fire Tripper) will kind of remind you of Kagome Higurashi (Inuyasha) given that they both are teenage girls from modern time ended up going to feudal-era Japan. 
 Shukumaru (Fire Tripper) is not a half-demon like Inuyasha, but both of them defend the main female character, there are differences but I won't spoil them.  But when you watch Fire Tripper you'll realize that's where Inuyasha got part of it's DNA from.  If you wanted to know where Inuyasha's inspiration come from, then I would recommend Fire Tripper.

Fire Tripper is basically Inuyasha Zero, Inuyasha: the beginning, Inuyasha: Origin.  Whatever you want to call it, every Inuyasha fans should watch Fire Tripper to know where one-half of Inuyasha's origin came from.
A slightly different side of the Fate universe. Even if you dont understand the Tsukihime references you would still probably like it due to the fate/stay night jokes

Similarities:
-Both are dramatic horrors
-Mysterious and creepy girl mcs who meet normal male mcs who are confused and have no idea what is going on.
-They both have a lot of gory and bloody action but Elfen Lied is more gory than Another

Differences:
-Elfen lied is a romance unlike Another
-Another is a Mystery unlike Elfen Lied
-One has a villainous mc (Elfen Lied) and the other has a heroic mc (Another).
-Elfen lied has a lot of nudity and Another has barely any nudity and no ecchi.

If you like one then you might like the other.

-Both are about fighting in the military 
-The girl mcs are half japanese and half german
-Both are quite violent but Aot is much more gory and bloody than Youjo Senki.
-Both have an overall dark theme but aot is more dramatic and depressing 
-The characters can move around with special equipment that are similar in some ways

Both Sailor Moon & Futari wa Precure are created by Toei, has magical girl concept similar to Sailor Moon.  It's directed by Daisuke Nishio of Dragonball Z fame.

Also this is for all the anime fan parent out there with young kid: If you have a daughter/child as young as 7 years old, but you can't show Sailor Moon in it's uncut form because of the dark subject matter later in the later season, just use Precure as a 7-8 year old friendly alternative if you're concerned about showing Sailor Moon's uncut content.  Precure is more child-friendly for below 9 years old girls if you want to improve their reading skill (Precure is subtitled after all, and the uncut version has no objectionable content other then mild language).

Wedding Peach will feel a lot like Sailor Moon when you watched the show.  I want to add that Sukehiro Tomita, the creator of Wedding Peach was also one of the writer for the Sailor Moon TV series.  Also Kazuko Tadano served as a character designer for both Sailor Moon & Wedding Peach TV series.  Also, some of the ideas in Wedding Peach may have derived from Sailor Moon too.  So if you want to watch something similar or feels like Sailor Moon, then Wedding Peach will fill in that same excitement.

Plot in Zankyou no Terror/Terror in Resonance has a cat & mouse plot, riddles, and plot intrigue that'll delight fans of Death Note.

Here's a tag line: What happened if you get the director of Cowboy Bebop anime TV series to direct Death Note?  You got Terror in Resonance.

Both are more "mature" takes on the high school romance genre. I think they depict love and the drama that comes with it in a more nuanced way than other HS romance anime. Araburu is a bit more lighthearted than Kuzu no Honkai, but both revel in the painful and destructive side of love. They also share the problem of having way lower MAL scores than their quality of writing deserves because they aren't fluffy happy feel good shows. Both shows have a few problematic characters that I can understand why people hate, but I love them all. Specifically, Hanabi and Niina. If you love one, you will probably love the other.

recommendation.title: Tsundere Akuyaku Reijou Liselotte to Jikkyou no Endou-kun to Kaisetsu no Kobayashi-san

recommendations.description: Both are otome game settings where the villainess has to avoid inevitable doom by courting a certain guy and there's assistance from external forces that would help her attain happy ending. Aileen has played the game before while Endo and Kobayashi are guiding the male lead.

A gansters story, cute little girl, paternity… if you like this subjects, these both series will be of your like.

However, just remember that the tone of both is completely different: Kumichou is almost full slice of life, while Buddy Daddies is action and comedy.

These shows use fantasy tropes and concepts, common in big action/adventure works, to instead tell simple, wholesome stories with comedic situations and a tone that overflows with charm. The atmosphere of both exude comfort matched by adorable art-styles, pastel colors and cute character designs. They'd both make a good pick for a relaxing watch.

Despite having completely different settings (1920s European setting in Gosick vs. Ancient China in Koukyuu no Karasu), they are both series centered around a mysterious female lead with an interesting backstory. Shouxue and Victorique's personalities and experiences have some similarities. Both series also have side stories that gradually lead into the main plot with a strong bond that forms between the female and male mcs. 

If you enjoyed Koukyuu no Karasu and would like something similar but with a Western setting, I'd recommend giving Gosick a try!
